awd_titl_txt: Toward a Unified Theory of Morphological Stability
awd_abstract_narration: The objective of this research is to discover and quantify                 the unifying theoretical aspects of morphological stability, a                  phenomenon concerned with spontaneous changes in shape of some                  material body under the influence of driving forces, such as                    capillarity, diffusion, heat flow, and stress.  Part I explores                 the morphological bifurcations of three dimensional shapes for a                continuous range of ellipsoidal shapes that include planes,                     cylinders, and spheres.  Recent observations on composite                       materials relate to this area.  Part II looks at global aspects                 of morphological instability and coarsening.  Mathematical                      relations developed by Gurtin are applied to dendritic                          solidification and late stage coarsening to characterize                        quantitatively the evolving morphologies.  Computer simulation                  is employed to study diffusion-limited aggregation of particles.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences
